newsitem.title: INDIA: India cites 10 airline near-misses since November.
newsitem.headline: India cites 10 airline near-misses since November.

text.p: There have been 10 near-misses mainly involving commercial airliners in Indian air space since the world's worst mid-air collision near Delhi in November, Civil Aviation Minister C.M. Ibrahim said on Thursday.

Ibrahim said in a written statement to parliament that the government was modernising air traffic services at Delhi and Bombay, insisting on proper maintainence of equipment and improving training to avoid further mishaps.

But he said there had been 10 close calls since a Saudi Arabia Airlines Boeing 747 and a Kazakh Ilyushin Il-76 freighter collided about 80 km (50 miles) west of New Delhi on November 12, killing all 349 people aboard the two aircraft.
He named four Indian airlines, the Indian Air Force and eight foreign airlines among those whose aircraft were reported in near-misses since November.
There were six cases, including three involving Indian passenger planes, reported in January alone, the statement said.
The mid-air collision in November focused world attention on flight safety in India, where economic growth has spurred tourism, putting pressure on outdated air traffic systems.
A multi-million-dollar plan to modernise radar and communications systems at major airports has fallen well behind schedule.
Due to go into operation six months ago, a state-of-the-art air traffic control system built by Raytheon Co of the United States has been held up by technical glitches.
In November Raytheon said the system would soon be ready for use.
India needs massive doses of private investment to build vital airport infrastructure and improve flight safety, aviation experts say.
India dismantled a state aviation monopoly as part of a series of sweeping economic reforms in 1991, opening its skies to a dozen private airlines.
India has five international and 87 domestic airports. Delhi and Bombay airports handle nearly half the total traffic.
